New Records: The Chicago White Sox set a franchise record with their 107th loss, breaking the previous mark set by the 1970 team. They also completed their first 0-10 homestand in franchise history and matched a season-high 12-game losing streak at home.
Key Match Events: Sean Manaea pitched two-hit ball over seven innings for the New York Mets, and Francisco Lindor hit his 29th home run to give the Mets an early lead. The Mets secured their fourth straight win and ninth in their last 13 games, pulling within a game of Atlanta for the NL wild card. The White Sox were shut out for the 15th time this season and have experienced 22 series sweeps, the highest in the majors.
Pre-Game Insights: The Mets' manager Carlos Mendoza emphasized the importance of maintaining intensity and focus during the game, reflecting on the team's performance during a challenging trip.
Post-Match Reflections: Mets manager Carlos Mendoza expressed pride in the team's resilience and locked-in performance. White Sox interim manager Grady Sizemore acknowledged Sean Manaea's strong outing but noted the team's frustration with the pitcher's limited workload due to a short leash and pitch count restrictions.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The game was played at Wrigley Field with a crowd of 16,887 fans. The Mets completed their sixth shutout of the season, all since July 11. Sean Manaea, who struck out five and walked two, has won 12 of his past 15 starts.
Others: The article mentions the White Sox's struggles, including a 4-36 record since the All-Star break and a 3-18 record under interim manager Grady Sizemore. It also notes that the White Sox have the worst home record in the majors, with a 12-game losing streak at Guaranteed Rate Field.
